title: Necrotizing Enterocolitis
setup_script: “A 30-week premature neonate on day 10 of life develops abdominal distension, feeding intolerance, and bloody stools. He has been on full enteral feeds. You are asked to evaluate this patient. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner reply: “Temperature 35.8 °C, HR 175 bpm, episodes of apnea and bradycardia.”
Examiner reply: “The abdomen is distended, shiny, tender, and bowel sounds are decreased. There is erythema of the abdominal wall.”
Examiner reply: “CBC shows leukocytosis with left shift or leukopenia, thrombocytopenia. Blood gas shows metabolic acidosis with elevated lactate.”
Examiner reply: “Radiograph demonstrates pneumatosis intestinalis and portal venous gas. Pneumoperitoneum is present if perforation occurs.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discontinues enteral feeds and places nasogastric decompression
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner reply: “The bowel is decompressed and distension decreases modestly.”
Examiner reply: “Antibiotics (ampicillin, gentamicin, metronidazole) are started, covering Gram-positive, Gram-negative, and anaerobic organisms.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides fluid resuscitation and parenteral nutrition
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner reply: “Perfusion is maintained, urine output improves, and nutrition is supported.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident monitors for signs of perforation
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner reply: “Clinical deterioration with abdominal wall erythema and pneumoperitoneum necessitate emergent laparotomy.”
Examiner reply: “Exploration reveals necrotic bowel. Resection with ostomy is performed. A second-look operation may be necessary.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays recognition or management
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner reply: “The patient progresses to shock, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and dies.”
Examiner reply: “Potential complications include short bowel syndrome, strictures, and neurodevelopmental delay.”
Examiner reply: “You explain the severity of the illness, prolonged hospitalization, and possible need for surgery.”

critical_decision_points: Early recognition of necrotizing enterocolitis in preterm infants
Initiation of bowel rest, gastric decompression, and broad-spectrum antibiotics
Monitoring for and promptly addressing perforation or necrosis requiring surgery
Supportive care with resuscitation and parenteral nutrition
Counseling families regarding prognosis and long-term complications
